title: feat: add `app.request` for set `get`, `post`
Express router: confused between query parameter and endpoint
body:
Hi Guys, 

![express-router-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16177376/74084073-1fa76980-4a91-11ea-9f7d-d88cf1fda88a.gif)
I am using express 4.17.1 and I have two routes:

1. /api/assessment/:id
2. /api/assessment/audit

If I keep "/api/assessment/audit" first in the router file,  the router correctly redirects request to the corresponding method. 

However if I keep "/api/assessment/:id" first, while calling "/api/assessment/audits",  it considers audit as id attribute and redirects request to the method of  "/api/assessment/:id".

Attach is the gif file for the same.

title: mark express-handlebars package as dead
body:
Express-handlebars no longer appears to be maintained, it is broken and the examples that come with the package to not work. 

Please update the list of template engines that "work out of the box" to reflect this situation. 

Thank you

title: Proper way to extend Request object in Typescript
body:
**Question:** Hello, what is the correct way to extend the Request object and add a new property?

Stackoverflow is flooded with options that didn't work to me.

I need it to have a different name, it can't be Request.

**Suggestion:** Where is it documented? Shouldn't it be more explicit?

title: Error ECONNABORTED sendFile
Server not sending last byte
body:
I don't know how to explain it, or at what code to point to. As far as I know this is the code that fails:

```javascript
module.exports = (req, res, next) => {
  if (req.session.passport) {
    next()
  }
  else {
    debugger
    req.log('You need to login')
    res.redirect('/login') // <--- Fails here
  }
}
```

Then I would test it with curl executed from inside the container:

```bash
root@68f037d2c428:~# curl -i -m1 http://localhost:3000
curl: (28) Operation timed out after 1000 milliseconds with 0 bytes received
root@68f037d2c428:~# curl -i -m5 http://localhost:3000
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
X-Powered-By: Express
Location: /login
Vary: Accept
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: 28
Set-Cookie: connect.sid=s%3A-O5W8zygEdzUmTtkGCAcfk4b8q6ORs79.KmwdqlKFXeKW5XjoTN09pBmgDIUacFzUCT1hOXG5JVc; Path=/; Expires=Sat, 07 Mar 2020 14:25:22 GMT; HttpOnly
Date: Thu, 06 Feb 2020 04:25:22 GMT
Connection: keep-alive

curl: (28) Operation timed out after 5000 milliseconds with 27 out of 28 bytes received
Found. Redirecting to /logi ## Suppose to be "Found. Redirecting to /login"
```

Is there any way to just disable the `Content-Length` header or how to correct the last bit not being sent? Or is this not the right place?

title: Just need some help.
body:
Ok, so, I'm trying to use `req.body.type` to get the selected option from a selector element in a form, 
```

<form action="/post" method="POST">

<select name="type">
<option name="headline" value="headline">Headline News</option>
<option name="local" value="local">Local News</option>
<option name="sports" value="sports">Sports</option>
<option name="editorial" value="editorial">Editorial</option>
</select>

<input type="submit" value="Post"
</form>
```

however, whenever i console log `req.body.type` it gives me `undefined`

On the other hand, I'm concerned that updates are interrupted by too long and unpredictable update cycles.
Do you have or have a specific release plan? I would like to hear if you have a plan.

body:
I am using the latest version of express.
Other query parameters are there, but the ones with dot are not.
Here is the part of 'req' object:

```
baseUrl: '/api/v1/bootcamps',
originalUrl: '/api/v1/bootcamps?housing=true&averageCost[lte]=10000&careers[in]=Business&location.city=MA',
_parsedUrl: Url {
    protocol: null,

},

}

title: Routers not working without hard refresh / no-cache
Calling URL by using param with colon shouldn't crash express
multiple query params with the same name gives you object instead of array
body:
If you send a request with multiple query params like this:
`http://localhost:3000/api/stock-prices?stock=GOOG&stock=APPL`
You will get this answer:
```  > node server.js

Listening on port undefined
stock length  = 2
type of stock = object
stock = [ 'GOOG', 'APPL' ]
```
so the type of stock should be an array, but it gives you Object.

title: Server responds to URL, then says it cannot respond to URL
Send non-primitive String as plain text
body:
Version 4.17.1

Current behaviour:
When I do
res.status(200).set('Content-Type', 'text/plain').send(new String("My wonderful string"))
I get a response with `"My wonderful string"`

Expected behaviour:
Response will equal `My wonderful string` without quotes

title: Allow response cookie sameSite value "Secure"
body:
As you probably saw the chrome console warning that says as below:
> A cookie associated with a cross-site resource at <URL> was set without the `SameSite` attribute. A future release of Chrome will only deliver cookies with cross-site requests if they are set with `SameSite=None` and `Secure`. You can review cookies in developer tools under Application>Storage>Cookies and see more details at <URL> and <URL>.
This console warning is not an error or an actual problem â€” Chrome is just spreading the word about this new standard to increase developer adoption.

When I trying to set `sameSite: 'Secure',` for cookie as opt I get an error that says:
> TypeError: option sameSite is invalid

title: We found req information not match the err catch by error handle middleware
Confusion when using "url params" and paths in "src" attributes on images.
body: # EDIT: This issue was created to comunicate a problem that I was having with express and had no clue of why it was happening. The answer from @dougwilson was quite satisfactory. Although, I decided to change a little the repo that I used as ilustration for what was happening and keep-it in Github just in case of anyone having the same confussion as me. * The answer from @dougwilson is the following: > Hello! > > This is not a bug, but a behavior of how web browsers interpret URLs on web pages. In your example, you are rendering a page at the URL of `/bug/on`. Then on that page, there are images with the relative URL of `bug1.jpeg`. The web browser needs to determine the absolute path to make a HTTP request. It does that by seeing that since you have to `/` before the jpeg path and no `/` after the on, then it makes it a sibling of the `on` file, resolving to `/bug/bug1.jpeg`. Since you defined the route of `/bug/:on`, that matches `/bug/bug1.jpeg` and calls that. > > When you use `/bug1.jpeg` in your image, that tells the web browser that you want it to resolve at the base of the server, so it resolves it to `/bug1.jpeg`, which does not match your `/bug/:on` route. > > If you have suggestions for what Express.js should specifically be doing (i.e. perhaps a code change in express), as far as I can tell, this is just perhaps confusion for how web browsers resolve URLs in order to load resources and not a bug in express. Please correct me if so and we can re-open this issue. ---------------------------------- # Original issue: I was having problems with some tags that wasn't correctly written. After a little of experimentation I found that a handler function was looping for each image tag with the same problem, making the server do unnecessary work. I dont know if is a knwon problem, or if it isn't a problem at all, but I prefer to advice, [link a repo with the bug's proof of concept](https://github.com/LautaroJayat/express-handlebars-little-bug) and write it's readme to give aditional information. # Express-Handlebars Bug ## Index * [Context](##Context) * [How Reproduce the Bug](##How) * [The Bug](##The) * [Operations that triggers the bug](##Operations) * [List of operations that don't trigger the bug](##List) ## Context ``` * Node Version:....................10.17.0 * NPM Version:.....................6.11.3 * Express Version:.................4.17.1 * Express-Handlebars Version:......3.1.0 ``` This bug involves the ```res.render()``` function that express provides in order to render one special case of a Handlebars view. In this proof of concept a function get triggered many times when someone hits and end-point that is handleded with: ``` router.get('/bug/:on', async (req, res) => { console.log('Im a Bug!') res.render('bug'); }); ``` where **```'/bug/:on```** is written in order to tell **express** that we are using **params** that will be pared and stored in ```req.params``` object; The problem occurs when you hit that kind of url and the function tries to render a view with an image coded like this: ``` ``` To be more specific: an `````` tag with its **src=""** atribute written without the **"/"** behind the name of the surce file, having the image in the root directory of the statics files that we previously setted in Express with the following piece of code: `app.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, 'images/')));`. ## The Bug When you hit that specific route, NodeJS will run the controller of that end-point one time for each image without **"/"**. I found that this only happens when the browser tries to create and print the actual image. ## How to reproduce this bug ### 1. Get the files Download this repo from https://github.com/LautaroJayat/express-img-path-little-problem.git . ### 2. Build If it's the first time, you can build and start the server by hitting `npm run install-bug` on your bash terminal. ### 3. Run If you allready has all dependencies installed and want only to run the server type `npm run bug` ### 4. Sart the server After that, you will have this message in the terminal: `Server on port 3000`. ### 5. Trigger the bug * Open your browser and go to `localhost:3000/bug/on` (or any other endpoint after "`bug/`"). * That will trigger the following piece of code: ``` router.get('/bug/:on', async (req, res) => { console.log('Im a Bug!') res.render('bug'); }); ``` * Go to the terminal where NodeJS is running the server and you will find not one, but 5 outputsof the `console.log('Im a Bug!)`. The terminal would look like this: ``` > node src/index.js Server on port 3000 Im a Bug! Im a Bug! Im a Bug! Im a Bug! Im a Bug! ``` ### 7. Without params If you hit the following end-points you won't trigger the bug * `localhost:3000/bug` * `localhost:300/bug2` The only difference between this two is that lastone has the `` tags with its source atribute startig with a **/** and the first doesn't. Notice that the output is the same: ``` > node src/index.js Server on port 3000 Im Not a Bug! ``` And also the handlers are almost the same, they only differs in the view that they are rendering: ``` router.get('/bug', async (req, res) => { console.log('Im Not a Bug!') res.render('bug'); }); router.get('/bug2', async (req, res) => { console.log('Im Not a Bug!') res.render('noBug'); }); ``` ### 8. With params but with correctly written tags Notice that the bug doesent appears when you call a simmilar route (that uses *params*) but has its *handlebars* file written correctly (with ``); * Go to `localhost:3000/bug2/on`. * This will trigger the following function: ``` router.get('/bug2/:on', async (req, res) => { console.log('Im Not a Bug!') res.render('noBug'); }); ``` with this output: ``` > node src/index.js Server on port 3000 Im Not a Bug! ``` ### 9. Checking with the debugger I found that if you check with the debugger you can see how the same operation gets executed once per image that hasn't got the **src** atributte with the slash preceding the filename. ## Operations that triggers the bug * Trying to acces `localhost:3000/bug/on` on Chrome 78.0.3904.108 (Build oficial) (64 bits) * Trying to acces `localhost:3000/bug/on` on Firefox 68.3.0esr (64-bit) * Trying to acces `localhost:3000/bug/on` on Brave 1.1.23 Chromium: 79.0.3945.88 (Official Build) (64-bit) ## List of operations that doesent trigger the bugs * Hitting `curl localhost:3000/bug/on` with curl 7.52.1 (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu) * Hitting `wget localhost:3000/bug/on` on GNU Wget 1.18;

title: [TypeError] Ionic React
body:
Working on an ionic react app and would like to use express with the following code:
```
const express = require('express');
const cors = require('cors');
const app = express();

  app.use(cors({
    origin:['http://localhost:8080'],
    methods:['GET','POST'],
    credentials: true // enable set cookie
}));
```

title: Can't see template changes until server is restarted
Cannot use res in unhandled errors if produced error with resp.status()
body:
Issue:
I am using an [unhandled error handler](https://expressjs.com/en/guide/error-handling.html) in express. Now I am facing an issue when I try to send a response (somewhere in the code) and give an undefined status code, it fails as it should and throw an error which is then intercepted by the unhandled error handler.

Everything is working the way it should except now the unhandled error handler cannot send a response back to user using **res** anymore. It is just skipping over it. 

The issue only persist when using *undefined status code* in the **res** beforehand.

title: check if express already listening to a port
body:
```
if(!app.listining()){
  app.listen(..)
}
```
what is the equivalent to app.listening() or maybe app.address()

note that both `app.listening()` and `app.address` don't actually exist in express.

title: Resolve method in response.js doesn't seem to work with Windows
body:
When running this program in a Windows environment, the /files/:names endpoint fails as a result of the file path being incorrect - though it works fine in a Linux environment. 
https://github.com/codebycaleb/express-files-example

After debugging, I found that the resolve method in response.js was adding "c:/" as a prefix to the path string (~ line 570), which messed things up.

title: docs: Instruct user to ensure package.json exists
body: This commit is made in reference to issue #4049

title: docs: added CHARTER.md
body:
As a member for the OpenJS foundation, we are required to have a well defined charter for the project.  I tried to pull it together based on the [template they provide](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/openjs-foundation/cross-project-council/master/PROJECT_CHARTER_TEMPLATE.md) and our existing docs. 

This is part of the onboarding process: https://github.com/openjs-foundation/project-onboarding/issues/15

title: docs: added CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
body:
As a member of the Open JS Foundation, we need to add the code of conduct to all project repos.  To get started I wanted to at least get it on the main repo, and then if we are good with this we can automate adding it to the rest.

This is part of the project onboarding: https://github.com/openjs-foundation/project-onboarding/issues/15

title: refactor: shallow arr clone using fast path
body:
Hi, 

This PR addresses the issue:
https://github.com/expressjs/express/issues/4141

I've opted for using the `Array.from` rather than the Spread operator for reasons such as:
1. https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/10307#issuecomment-386453017
2. Both have similar performance

(poc) benchmark:
http://jsben.ch/YCwrg

References:
[Speeding up spread elements](https://v8.dev/blog/spread-elements)
Ps. Notice how the current implementation is exactly like the one referenced on the blog post. [Here](https://v8.dev/blog/spread-elements#why-is-(or-were!)-spread-elements-slow%3F)

title: [Question] How to set the accepted maximum header size?
body:
Hi, on our application we get JWT access tokens from an external authentication server. 
Some of our users have a lot of claims and roles, making the token really large. When we set it into the `Authorization` header and send the request to express we get a response saying the request header is too large.
Is there a way to increase the maximum request header size on express or even make it unlimited?
Thanks.

title: Add "run on replit" badge

I added a "run on repl.it" badge that allows users to view a demo of express with one click, in their browser on [repl.it](https://repl.it). 
This is how it would look:

title: Is there a way for Response.json() to not escape certain string characters?
body:
I've come across a little annoying occurrence when trying to return a JSON featuring a string message which contains either a double quote or a backslash as literal characters.

I stumbled onto this when trying to return a JSON error response for a special character password rule.
`const errorMessage = 'Password must contain one special character: ! " # $ % & \' ( ) * + , - . / : ; < = > ? @ [ \\ ] ^ _ { | } ~';`
`return res.status(400).json({ message: errorMessage });`

Since I'm using single quotes for the message, I have to escape the single quote character as well as the backslash if I want them to show up as themselves in the string. And while debugging the errorMessage does indeed look as expected.

`Password must contain one special character: ! " # $ % & ' ( ) * + , - . / : ; < = > ? @ [ \ ] ^ _ { | } ~`

However once it goes back to the caller the JSON response looks like this:

`{
    "message": "Password must contain one special character: ! \" # $ % & ' ( ) * + , - . / : ; < = > ? @ [ \\ ] ^ _ { | } ~ "
}`

As can be seen, the double quote has a backslash in front of it, and the backslash itself seems to have one for itself as well.

The message works as expected if I return it just as a string via send:
`return res.status(400).json(errorMessage);`

So I'm guessing there's something going on with the Response.json() in particular which generates this kind of output. **Is there a way I can work around this?**

title: Http/2 Still not working?
body:
When are we going to see real progress on http2 support out of the box? we literally have thousands of scripts that depend on express and still not able to move to nodes http2 module. i've looked into the master, 5.0 and 5.x branches but there seams to be very few pushes into those repos to fix current backwards compatibility problems, firing up test server to check them and make incremental changes only to find ten other issues is getting frustrating. ALL these issues and errors go back a couple of years. due to the time and investment in express the only way forward at this time is to fork the stable branch and move on with a our own compatibility layer and then incrementally remove express from our workflow.

New issue created because it is frustrating reading through "issues" that date back years on this and see no real progress in the area of supporting the node built in http2 module.

[log.txt](https://github.com/expressjs/express/files/3909426/log.txt)

title: View resolver
body:
Are there any thoughts around adding the ability to provide a view/paritals resolver interface? 

I am wanting to add some basic CMS/Design section to our site and it would be ideal to store views and partials in a database. 

maybe something like this: 

```
   app.set('views', [myViewResolver, path.join(__dirname, 'views')]);
   app.set('view engine', 'ejs');
```
`ViewResolver` would expose a method `ViewResolver.get(view)` returning the view.

Thanks for your time.

title: acceptLanguages to return false when Accept-Language header is unspecified
body:
The documentation of `acceptLanguages` say:

> Returns the first accepted language of the specified languages, based on the requestâ€™s Accept-Language HTTP header field. If none of the specified languages is accepted, returns false.

However, when we receive a request without `Accept-Language` header, `req.acceptLanguages(myLanguagesArray)` returns the first element of `myLanguagesArray`, which is unexpected. The expected behavior is this API returns false, and downstream consumer can make decisions, such as; either to fallback to default language or send error to the caller.

Even without `Accept` and `Accept-Language` headers, first element of `myLanguagesArray` is returned.

title: could you add body-parser into the express framework
Use distinct session settings based on req domain
body:
Hello guys,

I have a web application that runs on localhost serving data through the port :30 to an also local web interface accessed via IP. Then, i set up a ngrok tunnel to redirect the server data through ssh to an online address accessed via an online web interface.

the 2 interfaces are identical, the only difference is that if the user is outside the network, then he can access the system through the online interface. I need this to work that way, cause i can not be 100% dependant on internet connection for my app to work, so if the user doesn't have internet but are in the local network, he can access the local address.

This is working fine for a couple of years, but since some time I started to experience in iOS, where after the login, the page returned to the login page, as the session was not started. It only works fine on Opera for iOS. In Android and Windows it works well in any navigator, but now Google Chrome started to show this message for the online interface:

> A cookie associated with a cross-site resource at http://***.ngrok.io/ was set without the `SameSite` attribute. A future release of Chrome will only deliver cookies with cross-site requests if they are set with `SameSite=None` and `Secure`. You can review cookies in developer tools under Application>Storage>Cookies and see more details at https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5088147346030592 and https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5633521622188032.

Currently my session setting is this:
```
exapp.use(session({ 
  name: 'session-name',
  secret: 'session-secret',
  resave: false,
  saveUninitialized: false,
  rolling: true,
  cookie: {
    secure: false,
    httpOnly: false
  }
}));
```

I can solve the problem by setting it like this:
```
exapp.set('trust proxy', 1);
exapp.use(session({
  name: 'session-name',
  secret: 'session-secret',
  resave: false,
  saveUninitialized: false,
  rolling: true,
  cookie: {
    sameSite: 'none',
    secure: true,
    httpOnly: false
  }
}));
```

But then i fall in another problem: the local interface. It doesn't work anymore because the local address is not HTTPS and even if i install a certificate i need to trust this in every navigator that will use the app.

My question is: Is there a way to use 2 types of settings for the express session? One for the remote interface which will be secure and cross-domain, and another for the local interface which will be on the same domain and insecure. If not, then a alternative suggestion will be welcome.

Thanks.

title: Charset specified in JSON content-type while it shouldn't
body:
I've read the previous closed issues, but in the meantime, the [CVE has been updated](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-gpvr-g6gh-9mc2) :-) :

> The Express web framework before 3.11 and 4.x before 4.5 for Node.js does not provide a charset field in HTTP Content-Type headers in 400 level responses, which might allow remote attackers to conduct cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks via characters in a non-standard encoding.

Now they specify that it occurs in 400 level responses.
Could we expect to fix?

Thank you
Thomas

title: Change the interface for setting application settings
body:
The interface `app.set(<name with space>, <value>)` feels a odd for setting values in a JavaScript framework. Also, its counterpart `app.get(<name>)` is a confusing twin of `app.get(path, callback [, callback ...])`, which is a router method.

I am proposing to implement application settings using getter-setter interfaces.

```
app.settings.trustProxy = true;
```

And get rid of `app.get(<name>)`.

Super major change, I know, but the next major version is a good time to make these interface improvements.

**Related issues**

1. https://github.com/expressjs/express/issues/2216
2. https://github.com/expressjs/express/issues/3997

title: message: connect ECONNREFUSED 127.0.0.1:port
no warning when setting  'secure' option for cookies and not using HTTPS
body:
When setting the `secure` option for a cookie without being on a HTTPS connection, express seems to silently ignore the whole cookie and not set any header. 

I would expect at least a warning, if not an error, as when I set `secure: true` I am absolutely planning to make this cookie available over HTTPS only and will expect some kind of explicit failure when this is not the case.

title: Just a simple question I have.
Are all route "handler functions" considered middleware functions?
body:
In the docs it states :

> Middleware functions are functions that have access to the request object (req), the response object (res), and the next middleware function in the applicationâ€™s request-response cycle.

However in a route callback function, or "handler function", we often don't add the `next` parameter when it's not needed, such as in this simple example from the docs:
`app.get('/', (req, res) => res.send('Hello World!'))`.

Is the function `(req, res) => res.send('Hello World!')` in the example above still considered a middleware function even though it doesn't have access to the next middleware function (since `next` wasn't declared as a parameter)?

I apologize if this is not a good place to ask this question. I just noticed quite a a lot of differences in how people define or understand exactly what a middleware function is in Express, when looking online at various websites. I wanted to go to the source ðŸ˜„.

title: Unable to send data in res.json?

title: req.params is an object when route is defined with regexp
body:
[The doc states](https://expressjs.com/en/4x/api.html#req.params) that req.params is an array when the route is defined with a regexp but it is still in fact an object.

I made an example project : https://github.com/nleclerc/expressbugtest
